metadata.title: 2 Twelve E3 Lab IaaS

value.description:
This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

The ARB reviews and updates all E3LabIaas Information Security Policy at least every 3 years.  The CloudOps reviews and updates the E3LabIaas Procedures every year during the annual system review.

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

The ARB reviews and updates all E3LabIaas Information Security Policy at least every 3 years.  The CloudOps reviews and updates the E3LabIaas Procedures every year during the annual system review.

Part b2

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

Service Provider Responsibility:

2 Twelve Solutions: 2 Twelve has identified two account types for the environment, one for each role – CloudOps team and Infrastructure team members. CloudOps team has administrative access to the environment.

Application: Application accesses are specific to each customer. CloudOps admins do not have access to customer application. After the creation of a customer admin account during the customer onboard process, administrators do not access the system unless requested. Admins can only access the OS layer of those instances.

For the authentication process, the first step requires the user’s private SSH key to authenticate against the public SSH key on the host.

Operating System: Authorized administrators access operating systems by authenticating through the SSH. CloudOps team are considered as privileged users. All users must have a valid SSH key. Users must have a matching public SSH key on the operational system to establish connection with that host. Connections are enforced through IDPS and firewalls.

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Solutions Responsibility:

CloudOps team are privileged users in the environment. Requesting managers submit access requests as Change Requests.  When the ARB approves a request, system administrators will perform user account setup.

Application:  CloudOps team are designated as account managers for infrastructure tools (shared services). The customer is responsible for the account management actions for their Application instances. All infrastructure remote access is provided through SSH connections to the host.

Operating System:  CloudOps team are considered as privileged users in the environment. The requesting manager initiate the account request/change process. CloudOps personnel will proceed with the normal access approval process through the ARB. The SSH configuration enforces the user to public-private key authentication. This entails that each user has a unique set of SSH Keys where the public key is added to the SSH host through Ansible. When a user attempts to login, user must present his or her private key installed on the workstation. Once connected to the system, all changes are handled by executing the prepared Ansible playbooks from the change management process against the scope of the change.

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

2 Twelve has established two groups for system accounts – CloudOps team and InfraOps team. Users who require administrative privileges within the instances are designated as CloudOps team. Users who require administrative privileged at the infrastructure layer are designated as the InfraOps team.

Application, Operating System:  User permissions are granted on the principle of least privilege and role based access needs, as depicted in the E3LabIaas Access and Identity Management Plan. Ticketing system is used to document and enforce the defined workflow for all account changes. The conditions for group and role membership are dictated by the function of the individual’s role to ensure those accounts only perform the functions commensurate with business needs.

Customer Responsibility:

Customers are responsible for establishing roles and groups within the application and the requirements for membership in such roles and groups.

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

2 Twelve has established two groups for system accounts – CloudOps team and InfraOps team. Users who require administrative privileges within the instances are designated as CloudOps team. Users who require administrative privileged at the infrastructure layer are designated as the InfraOps team.

Application:  Application accesses are specific to each customer. CloudOps members do not have access to customer application. After the creation of a customer admin account during the customer onboard process, administrators have no access to the customer application. Admins can only access the OS layer of those instances.

For the authentication process, the first step requires the user’s private SSH key to authenticate against the public SSH key on the host.

Operating System:  CloudOps team are considered as privileged users in the environment. The requesting manager initiate the account request/change process. CloudOps personnel will proceed with the normal access approval process through the ARB. The SSH configuration enforces the user to public-private key authentication. This entails that each user has a unique set of SSH Keys where the public key is added to the SSH host through Ansible. When a user attempts to login, user must present his or her private key installed on the workstation. Once connected to the system, all changes are handled by executing the prepared Ansible playbooks from the change management process against the scope of the change.

Customer Responsibility:

Customers are responsible for establishing roles and groups within the application and the requirements for membership in such roles and groups.

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

The SO must approve requests to create information system accounts. Approval are documented and tracked through service tickets. Configuration management process is being followed through issue tracking and documented in E3LabIaas Access and Identity Management Plan.

Application:  The SO must approve requests to create accounts on shared services. Approval are documented and tracked through service tickets. Configuration management process is being followed through issue tracking and documented in E3LabIaas Access and Identity Management Plan.

Operating System:  The SO must approve requests to create information system accounts. This includes access to the infrastructure. Approval are documented and tracked through service tickets.

Customer Responsibility:

Customers are responsible for designating approvers for application accounts.

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

Application, Operating System:  Accounts are created, enabled, modified, disabled, and removed following E3LabIaas Access and Identity Management Plan. Once the ticket is approved by the ISSO and SO, the CloudOps team will create the account(s), modify access rights, or disable accounts.

Customer Responsibility:

Customers are responsible for creating, enabling, modifying, disabling, and removing application accounts according to their respective account management procedures.

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

2 Twelve monitors the use of system accounts through the use of audit logs. Activities on the host, are monitored and logged via Logging server. 2 Twelve monitors activity for privilege user accounts and account activity. Audit logs are forwarded to Logging server for review.

The following processes are in place to support account activity monitoring.

• All account activity is logged by the logging facilities defined in the response to AU-2, and events are automatically sent to a SIEM tool

• The CloudOps team monitors (using a SIEM tool) for system-wide account activity for application, and operating system.

• Account creation, modification, and deletion events generate an alert in the SIEM tool for investigation.

• Account additions, modifications, or deletions require a ticket before execution.

• If any abnormal account activity is identified, the CloudOps Team is immediately notified through email.

• After triage by the CloudOps Team, activities are tracked using a ticketing system.

Reference AU-2 for additional details on audit events generated in the environment.

Application:  2 Twelve monitors the use of system accounts through the use of audit logs. Activities on the host, are monitored and logged via Logging server. 2 Twelve monitors activity for privilege user accounts and account activity. Audit logs are forwarded to Logging server for review.

Operating System:  2 Twelve monitors the use of system accounts through instance itself. Logs from IDPS, firewalls, audit, and system events are fed into Logging server. Pre-configured thresholds and search events are set up in Logging server and will generate alert if certain threshold is exceeded. CloudOps team will receive an alert via email or ticketing system.

Customer Responsibility:

Customers are responsible for the review of their user actions. Application logs are available through the platform to privileged customer users.

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

CloudOps team is notified through ticketing system when a user account requires modification or disablement due to change in role (change in privileges) or termination. 2 Twelve’s Human Resources is responsible to notify CloudOps team of the terminated employee in order to revoke access to the environment. CloudOps is responsible for revoking terminated personnel’s user’s SSH keys.

Application, Operating System:  2 Twelve utilizes the ticketing system to manage the entire lifecycle of accounts.  Changes to the accounts are initiated by customer. When the change is approved, the CloudOps team are notified via email when accounts are no longer needed due to termination, transfer or system usage change. When users are terminated, a notification is sent to HR and the respective manager. When users are promoted or transferred to another group, user role and access rights are automatically reviewed by the new manager and any permission not required in the new role is revoked. The user’s permissions are changed after proper approvals and authorization from the respective group owners is received. The ticketing system retains the tickets associated with changes to accounts and includes approvals for the changes. Personnel termination process described in PS-3.

Customer Responsibility:

Customers are responsible for notifying their account managers when accounts are no longer required, when users are terminated or transferred, or when system usage or need-to-know changes.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

Users are authorized by role; specifically, users are assigned either to the CloudOps team group or the InfraOps Team group. CloudOps team is responsible for administrative activities on the instances. InfraOps Team is responsible for infrastructure level resources.

Application, Operating System:  Users are authorized access to the environment based on valid access authorization or intended usage. Authorization of access assignments, valid access authorization, and intended system usage are initiated by each manager who ensures that:

• Access being requested is appropriate to the individual’s role and validates that the employee has completed the appropriate technical and security training for the access type being requested.

• Tickets are created in the ticketing system relating to each request

• All access (including permissions, membership to roles and groups, etc.) is required to follow the ‘need to know’ and ‘least privilege’ principles

• User permissions are granted on the principle of least privilege and role based access needs, as depicted in the E3LabIaas Access and Identity Management Plan.

Customer Responsibility:

Customers are responsible for authorizing user access to the application based on their intended system usage.

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

The ARB review all user accounts annually to ensure compliance with account management requirements.

Application, Operating System:  User accounts are reviewed for compliance by the SO and CloudOps at least annually. Account permissions and privileges are being reviewed at least quarterly by CloudOps as described in CM-5(5). Only accounts with valid access authorizations for the environment are permitted. Any accounts determined to be unnecessary due to prior termination or transfer are removed or disabled in accordance with account management policies and procedures.

Customer Responsibility:

Customers are responsible for reviewing user access to the application.

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

Shared/group credentials are tightly controlled in the environment; all users authenticate to systems using unique SSH keys.

Application, Operating System:  Shared/group credentials are tightly controlled in the environment. Default root accounts are considered emergency account.

Customer Responsibility:

Customers are responsible for issuing and reissuing shared/group account credentials when individuals are removed from security groups for the application.

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

2 Twelve employs tickets to track account management activities. Privileged user accounts within the environment is deployed using Ansible scripts. Logging server is leveraged to monitor user accounts within the environment.

Application, Operating System:  2 Twelve uses automated mechanisms to support the management of accounts for the application.  Tickets are used for the tracking and approval of information system account creation. Account creations for the infrastructure are completed through Ansible playbooks. Account activities are monitored through Logging server. Management of infrastructure accounts is tracked and documented through ticketing system. The ticketing system provides automated workflow for managing the following aspects of account management:

• Requests for accounts.

• Approvals for account creation, modification, and removal − Permission changes.

• Notifications to account owners and manager for various account management tasks.

Customer Responsibility:

The Customer is responsible for employing automated mechanisms to support the management of application accounts including:

• Permission changes

• Requests for accounts.

• Provisioning endpoints and new users.

• Approvals for account creation, modification, and removal

2 Twelve Responsibility:

2 Twelve does not regularly use temporary or emergency accounts. If deployed, 2 Twelve disables all temporary and emergency accounts within 30 days.

Application, Operating System:  2 Twelve does not regularly use temporary or emergency accounts for the applications. If deployed, 2 Twelve disables all temporary and emergency accounts within 30 days. All accounts must go through the processes defined in AC-2.

Customer Responsibility:

Customers are responsible for reviewing user access to their applications.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

Application:  Account inactivity on Qualys SaaS is enforced through password expiration, Qualys passwords are configured to expire after 60 days. Logging server and Security scanner access requires authentication through the bastion host. Bastion host and hosts password are configured to expire after 60 days.

Database:  admins do not have direct access to customer applications nor the data in the database. Database is accessed through application where customer makes request to application and application request goes to database.

Operating System:  Account inactivity is enforced through password expiration. Bastion host and hosts password are configured to expire after 60 days.

Customer Responsibility:

Customers are responsible for monitoring the usage of user accounts and disabling after a period of inactivity.

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

Application, Operating System:  For the applications, all account management activities, such as creation, modification, enabling, disabling and/or removing accounts are logged and forwarded to logging server for review.  All account changes such as request; approval, creation, modification, and deletion of access to resources in the environment are tracked, documented, and retained in ticketing system. The CloudOps team is notified via email of all account management activities.

Customer Responsibility:

The Customer is responsible for automatically auditing account creation, modification, enabling, disabling, and removal actions, and notify organization personnel.

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

User permissions are granted on the principle of least privilege and role based access needs, as depicted in the E3LabIaas Access and Identity Management Plan. Ticketing system is used to document and enforce the defined workflow for all account changes. Approved users will be added to Ansible playbook and granted access into the environment. The host is the used to enforce privilege access. Users must provide a valid SSH key to the host.

Application: Application accesses are specific to each customer. Network ACLs are leveraged to enforce access flow and provide logical separation such that customers only have access to their own environment. Application front end users must authenticate through MFA or SAML 2.0 token. Reverse proxies enforces TLS1.2 encryption to protect the communication session. Administrators do not have access to client applications. Access to Logging server, Security scanner is limited to authorized personnel based on role based access on the principle of least privilege.

Operating System: Authorized administrators access operating systems by authenticating through the host. All users must have a valid SSH key. Users must have a matching public SSH key on the instance to establish connection with that host. Connections are enforced through network ACLs. Creation, modification, and deletion of users and groups must go through the defined CM process and requested through ticketing system for ARB approval.

Customer Responsibility:

The Customer is responsible for enforcing approved authorizations for logical access to application and system resources in accordance with applicable access control policies.
Information flow for the operating system is enforced network ACLs. Firewalls are configured to deny by default and only allow by exception.

Information flow is enforced policy enforcement points and network ACLs, which define the allowed traffic flows throughout the environment and across the boundary. Firewalls are configured to deny-by-default and only allow by exception.

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

2 Twelve separates host level administrator activities conducted by the CloudOps team from the infrastructure activities conducted by the InfraOps team. CloudOps team is provided privileges to launch Ansible scripts to configure the environment, while the InfraOps team has privilege access to the configure the underlying compute, storage, network infrastructure. CloudOps team has administrative access to Logging server and security scanning. Please refer to AC-2(b) for more information on account management and the approval and use of security groups in the role-based access schemes. Separation of Duties is further defined through 2 Twelve Separation of Duties Matrix.

Application:  2 Twelve separates administrator activities conducted by the CloudOps team from the infrastructure activities conducted by the InfraOps team. CloudOps team is provided privileges to launch Ansible scripts to configure the environment, while the InfraOps team has privilege access to the configure the underlying compute, storage, network infrastructure.

Operating System: 2 Twelve separates administrator activities conducted by the CloudOps team from the infrastructure activities conducted by the InfraOps team. CloudOps team is provided privileges to launch Ansible scripts to configure the environment, while the InfraOps team has privilege access to the configure the underlying compute, storage, network infrastructure.

Customer Responsibility:

The Customer is responsible for developing and maintaining a separation of duties for privileged and non-privileged users.

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

2 Twelve separates host level administrator activities conducted by the CloudOps team from the infrastructure activities conducted by the InfraOps team. CloudOps team is provided privileges to launch Ansible scripts to configure the environment, while the InfraOps team has privilege access to the configure the underlying compute, storage, network infrastructure. CloudOps team has administrative access to Logging server and security scanning. Please refer to AC-2(b) for more information on account management and the approval and use of security groups in the role-based access schemes. Separation of Duties is further defined through 2 Twelve Separation of Duties Matrix.

Application:  2 Twelve separates administrator activities conducted by the CloudOps team from the infrastructure activities conducted by the InfraOps team. CloudOps team is provided privileges to launch Ansible scripts to configure the environment, while the InfraOps team has privilege access to the configure the underlying compute, storage, network infrastructure.

Operating System: 2 Twelve separates administrator activities conducted by the CloudOps team from the infrastructure activities conducted by the InfraOps team. CloudOps team is provided privileges to launch Ansible scripts to configure the environment, while the InfraOps team has privilege access to the configure the underlying compute, storage, network infrastructure.

Customer Responsibility:

The Customer is responsible for developing and maintaining a separation of duties for privileged and non-privileged users.

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

2 Twelve separates host level administrator activities conducted by the CloudOps team from the infrastructure activities conducted by the InfraOps team. CloudOps team is provided privileges to launch Ansible scripts to configure the environment, while the InfraOps team has privilege access to the configure the underlying compute, storage, network infrastructure. CloudOps team has administrative access to Logging server and security scanning. Please refer to AC-2(b) for more information on account management and the approval and use of security groups in the role-based access schemes. Separation of Duties is further defined through 2 Twelve Separation of Duties Matrix.

Application:  2 Twelve separates administrator activities conducted by the CloudOps team from the infrastructure activities conducted by the InfraOps team. CloudOps team is provided privileges to launch Ansible scripts to configure the environment, while the InfraOps team has privilege access to the configure the underlying compute, storage, network infrastructure.

Operating System: 2 Twelve separates administrator activities conducted by the CloudOps team from the infrastructure activities conducted by the InfraOps team. CloudOps team is provided privileges to launch Ansible scripts to configure the environment, while the InfraOps team has privilege access to the configure the underlying compute, storage, network infrastructure.

Customer Responsibility:

The Customer is responsible for developing and maintaining a separation of duties for privileged and non-privileged users.

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

Privileged users are assigned roles and privileges only sufficient to complete their assigned responsibilities. CloudOps team is assigned access to the host with privileges to launch Ansible scripts for the configuration and maintenance of the environment. CloudOps team are assigned full access to logging server and security scanner.

Application, Operating System:  Privileged users are assigned roles and privileges only sufficient to complete their assigned responsibilities. CloudOps team is assigned access to the host with privileges to launch Ansible scripts for the configuration and maintenance of the environment. CloudOps team are assigned full access to logging server and security scanner. E3LabIaas employs both the ‘need to know’ and ‘least privilege’ principles, only allowing employee access to information systems necessary to accomplish assigned tasks, in accordance with organizational missions and business functions and explicitly authorizing access to specific information and information systems. Account activity is monitored through Logging Server. All activities associated with granting, modifying and revoking privileged access to accounts and resources within the environment must:

• Have the request(s) tied to a ticket in the approved ticketing and tracking system

• Have appropriate, documented approval from the data or resource owner

• Follow approved change management procedures

Please refer to related controls AC-2, AC-3, and CM-7 for additional information.

Customer Responsibility:

The customer is responsible for employing the principle of least privilege for all access to the application.

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

2 Twelve explicitly authorizes access to CloudOps team for the purpose of deploying Ansible scripts to configure and maintain the environment. 2 Twelve also authorizes access to the infrastructure console for specific individuals. The CloudOps team has administrative access to security scanner and has administrative access to logging server.

Application, Operating System:  All access to systems in the environment is deny by default and must be explicitly authorized following the principle of “need to know” and “least privilege”. Authorization includes access to security related functions such as establishing system accounts and configuring access authorizations (permissions, privileges).

Customer Responsibility:

The Customer is responsible for explicitly authorizing access to the application and defined security functions.

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

Privileged users only access the environment to conduct system security functions and use their sole accounts for this access.

Application, Operating System:  Only privileged users, such as members of the CloudOps and InfraOps teams have access to the tool accounts (Logging server, Security scanner) for the purpose of performing administrative or security control implementation functions. Infrastructure access is restricted to CloudOps team, InfraOps team. Separation of Duties matrix defines privileged and non-privileged access for users performing specific function. At this time, both CloudOps and InfraOps accounts are considered as privileged accounts.

Customer Responsibility:

The Customer is responsible for requiring users of information system accounts, or roles, with access to the application security functions, use non-privileged accounts or roles, when accessing non-security functions.

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

Only CloudOps team and InfraOps team members are provided privileged accounts in the environment.

Application, Operating System:  Privileged accounts are restricted to members of the CloudOps and InfraOps team. CloudOps team is provided administrative privileges for the environment. Through the “least privilege” and “need to know” principles, 2 Twelve restricts access to privileged accounts to a very limited number of personnel with approved roles and responsibilities. Individuals with the following roles and responsibilities are given access to privileged accounts:

• System Owner, 2 Twelve Leadership

• Services Manager, 2 Twelve Leadership

• Information System Security Officer

• Operations Manager, CloudOps Team

• Infrastructure Operations Manager, InfraOps Team

Note: All access that is not specifically granted to a user is denied by default.

Customer Responsibility:

The customer is responsible for restricting privileged accounts on the information system to defined roles for the application.

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

Privileged functions are captured and forwarded to logging server for review and monitoring by the CloudOps team.

Application:  All privileged functions from the application are captured by logging sidecars and forwarded to logging server for review by the CloudOps team. Customers can request a report of privilege function logs on a as needed basis. When pre-defined events or triggers are detected, appropriate team are notified of the event through alerts. The information systems produce audit records that contain sufficient information to, at a minimum, establish what type of event occurred, when (date and time) the event occurred, where the event occurred, the source and destination addresses, user/process identifiers, event descriptions, success/fail indications, filenames involved, and access control or flow control rules invoked.

Operating system: All privileged actions such as sudo and yum update are captured and forwarded to logging server for near real time monitoring and alerting. Actions from hosts and all other instances are configured to feed all activities to logging server. When pre-defined events or triggers are detected, appropriate team are notified of the event through alerts. The information systems produce audit records that contain sufficient information to, at a minimum, establish what type of event occurred, when (date and time) the event occurred, where the event occurred, the source and destination addresses, user/process identifiers, event descriptions, success/fail indications, filenames involved, and access control or flow control rules invoked.

Customer Responsibility:

The Customer is responsible for ensuring the information system audits the execution of privileged functions.

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

Non-privileged users in the application are controlled by role-based assignments to prevent execution of privileged functions. No non-privileged users have any other access to the environment.

Application, Operating system:  Non-privileged users in the environment are controlled by role-based assignments to prevent execution of privileged functions. No non-privileged users have any other access to the environment. Separation of Duties matrix defines privileged and non-privileged access for users performing specific function. Policies apply a deny by default and least privilege enforcements to ensure non-privileged users cannot access privilege security functions.

Customer Responsibility:

The Customer is responsible for ensuring the application prevents non-privileged users from executing privileged functions.

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

Application: For security scanner, account lockouts are set to maximum of 3 tries, after the third unsuccessful attempt, the user account is locked until unlocked by an administrator. For logging server, account lockouts are set to maximum of 3 tries, after the third unsuccessful attempt, the user account is locked until unlocked by an administrator

Operating System: 2 Twelve personnel use SSH cryptographic keys to access hosts and locks out after three (3) failed login attempts are implemented on all environment instances. Once the threshold is met, the source IP will be blocked for five minutes.  The only way to regain access is to wait for five minutes and try to access again after the source IP has been unblocked.

Customer Responsibility:

The customer is responsible for enforcing a limit of consecutive invalid login attempts within a designated period according to the customer defined policy value.

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

Application: For security scanner, account lockouts are set to maximum of 3 tries, after the third unsuccessful attempt, the user account is locked until unlocked by an administrator. For logging server, account lockouts are set to maximum of 3 tries, after the third unsuccessful attempt, the user account is locked until unlocked by an administrator. Automatic locking is implemented by the application based on configured policies.

Operating System: 2 Twelve personnel use SSH cryptographic keys to access hosts and locks out after three (3) failed login attempts are implemented on all environment instances. Once the threshold is met, the source IP will be blocked for five minutes.  The only way to regain access is to wait for five minutes and try to access again after the source IP has been unblocked. Automatic locking is implemented by IDPS called Fail2Ban which scans access logs for invalid logon attempts and automatically applies blocks by apply drop packet rules at the host firewalls.

Customer Responsibility:

The customer is responsible for enforcing a limit of consecutive invalid login attempts within a designated period according to the customer defined policy value.

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

The system warning banner is displayed prior to access to the host. The banner informs users that the usage may be monitored and subject to audit, unauthorized use is prohibited, and use of the system is considered consent to such monitoring.

Application, Database, Operating System: The system warning banner is displayed prior to access to the shared services, and instances. The application banner is configured in accordance with requirements from the 2 Twelve customers. The banner informs users that the usage may be monitored and subject to audit, unauthorized use is prohibited, and use of the system is considered consent to such monitoring.

Users are presented with the following warning message and much acknowledge prior to accessing environment:

“Authorized uses only. All activity may be monitored and reported.”

Customer Responsibility:

It is the customer responsibility to ensure that there is a notification or warning banner before granting access to the system that provides privacy and security notices consistent with FedRAMP requirements and federal laws, Executive Orders, directives, policies, regulations, standards, and guidance.

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

The system warning banner is displayed prior to access to the host. The banner informs users that the usage may be monitored and subject to audit, unauthorized use is prohibited, and use of the system is considered consent to such monitoring.

Application, Database, Operating System: The system warning banner is displayed prior to access to the shared services, and instances. The application banner is configured in accordance with requirements from the 2 Twelve customers. The banner informs users that the usage may be monitored and subject to audit, unauthorized use is prohibited, and use of the system is considered consent to such monitoring.

Users are presented with the following warning message and much acknowledge prior to accessing environment:

“Authorized uses only. All activity may be monitored and reported.”

Customer Responsibility:

It is the customer responsibility to ensure retains the notification message or banner on the screen until users acknowledge the usage conditions and take explicit actions.

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

The environment is intended for private consumption. This requirement is not applicable to the system.

Application, Database, Operating System:  The environment is for private consumption by a designated 2 Twelve customer. This requirement is not applicable.

Customer Responsibility:

It is the customer responsibility to ensure that for all publicly accessible systems there is a notification or warning banner before granting access to the system that provides privacy and security notices consistent with FedRAMP requirements and federal laws, Executive Orders, directives, policies, regulations, standards, and guidance.

Additional FedRAMP Requirements and Guidance

Requirement 1: The service provider shall determine elements of the cloud environment that require the System Use Notification control.  The elements of the cloud environment that require System Use Notification are approved and accepted by the JAB/AO.

Requirement 2: The service provider shall determine how System Use Notification is going to be verified and provide appropriate periodicity of the check.  The System Use Notification verification and periodicity are approved and accepted by the JAB/AO.  If performed as part of a Configuration Baseline check, then the % of items requiring setting that are checked and that pass (or fail) check can be provided.

Requirement 3: If not performed as part of a Configuration Baseline check, then there must be documented agreement on how to provide results of verification and the necessary periodicity of the verification by the service provider.  The documented agreement on how to provide verification of the results are approved and accepted by the JAB/AO.

AC-8 What is the solution and how is it implemented?

Req. 1

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

As all privileged users must access the environment through SSH, the system warning banner is applied at the host during SSH session initiation.

Application, Database, Operating System:  As all privileged users must access the environment through SSH, the system warning banner is applied at the host during SSH session initiation. The system use notifications contain explicit action language that must be taken to accept the notification before continuing to access systems.

Customer Responsibility:

It is the customer responsibility to determine elements of the cloud environment that require the System Use Notification control.

Req. 2

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

The warning banner is defined as part of the configuration, which is deployed through ansible. Any deviation from the ansible settings will be re-applied at each deployment. In addition, the banner display and content is check manually by the CloudOps during each infrastructure access.

Customer Responsibility:

It is the customer responsibility to determine how System Use Notification is going to be verified and provide appropriate periodicity of the check.

Req. 3

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

The warning banner is defined as part of the configuration, which is deployed through ansible. Any deviation from the ansible settings will be re-applied at each deployment. In addition, the banner display and content is check manually by the CloudOps during each infrastructure access.

Customer Responsibility:

For more detailed implementation of the monitoring in place, refer to AU-2 and AU-3 of this SSP.

Application: Auditable events are logged and sent to the logging server in real time. 2 Twelve auditable events are selected using a risk-based approach that takes into account their information security standards. The following are deemed to be auditable events:

• All administrator privileged functions

• Authentication checks

• Authorization checks

• Data deletions, data access, data changes, and permission changes

Operating System: Events captured in OSSEC, ClamAV and rkhunter are forwarded to Logging server. 2 Twelve monitors industry-wide security threats and has defined the following events as auditable events that should be captured in system audit logs based on mission/business needs:

• Failed logon attempts

• File integrity monitoring

• Account and/or profile changes and deletions

• Changes to system security settings and parameters

• System shutdowns/restarts

• Use of privileged accounts and/or activities

2 Twelve Responsibility:

2 Twelve E3LabIaaS Information Security Policy directs the activities within the Access Management Plan. The plan addresses purpose, scope, responsibilities (including management commitment), coordination among organizational entities, and compliance requirements to meet the FedRAMP control implementation requirements for the access control family of a moderate baseline. The plan specifically addresses procedures or processes related to:

• Information Access Restriction

• The Request Fulfillment Process for Provisioning Access

• The Periodic Review of Access

• The Revocation of Access

• The Separation of Duties

• Access Control to Program Source Code

• Authenticator Device Management

• Encryption

All procedures that are captured in Thanos, 2 Twelve Solution’s document repository management system, are reviewed on an annual basis by the 2 Twelve Leadership and ARB. The ARB consists of the InfraOps, CloudOps and relevant decision makers. The ARB is responsible for notifying stakeholders when changes are made and approved by the ARB. This may require the creation of new documentation or reviewing and updating current procedures, annually or as needed; and policies every 3 years or as needed.

The CloudOps and Management team are responsible for reviewing policies and procedures. The team composition includes the following:

• CloudOps (Operations, Network, OS, Databases, Applications stakeholders); and

• 2 Twelve Solution Leadership (CEO, System Owner; and Director of Engineering Services, InfraOps);

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

2 Twelve Responsibility:

2 Twelve uniquely identifies and authenticates organizational users. The E3LabIaaS environment uses the following technologies to uniquely identify and authenticate organizational users (as referenced in AC-2).

Application:

Customer Authentication through SSO or MFA

Application front end users must authenticate through MFA or SAML 2.0 token. The application(s) are responsible for providing data in transit encryption, as required according to their organizational policy, to protect the communication session. 2 Twelve administrators do not have access to client applications.

Operating System: Each user has a unique username and associated SSH key on the host. Usernames are defined in the format of firstname.lastname. In the case of multiple personnel with the same name, numerical values are added at the end of the username.

Administrator access for all devices within the environment requires key authentication to the host. This is done by installing the administrator’s SSH public key onto the hosts that they have a need to access. 2 Twelve admins do not have direct access to customer data.  They have admin access to the OS level and files residing on the filesystem; however they are only allowed limited direct access to the hosts to perform troubleshooting, as required, and all administrative actions must be performed through automation. Patches and updates are accomplished through Ansible.

Customer Responsibility:

It is the customer responsibility to ensure information system uniquely identifies and authenticates organizational users.

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

2 Twelve does not reuse any account names or identifiers.

Application: E3LabIaaS tools (logging, security scanning) accounts can be deactivated. Account creation and disablement requires approval through a service ticket. When accounts are no longer needed, they are disabled or inactivated, but never removed.

E3LabIaaS instances are identified by the hostname and IP address. The E3LabIaaS inventory contains the IP address and host name associated with each device within the authorization boundary.

Operating System: 2 Twelve uses a naming convention for user accounts that follows [first name].[last name]. In the case of multiple personnel with the same name, numerical values are added at the end of the username. Account disablement is done through ansible, when accounts are to be disabled, the account name is maintained as commentary within the user list.

Device E3LabIaaS utilizes instance hostname and IP addresses as device identifier. The E3LabIaaS inventory contains the IP address and host name associated with each device within the authorization boundary. When new instances are deployed, CloudOps to review to ensure new instances does not reuse any disabled identifier within the past 2 years.

Customer Responsibility:

It is the customer responsibility to prevent the reuse of identifiers for at least two years.

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

Application:  Account inactivity is enforced through account policies in the SSO solution. Accounts are disabled after 60 days of inactivity.

Operating System:  Account inactivity is enforced through password expiration. Hosts password are configured to expire after 60 days.

Customer Responsibility:

It is the customer responsibility to disable the identifier after at least ninety days of inactivity.

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

2 Twelve personnel who require administrator access to the E3LabIaaS environment are verified as part of the hiring process. The hiring process includes a background check to include the verification of the individual’s identity and address. As part of the team onboarding process the 2 Twelve personnel with administrator access to E3LabIaaS creates required unique SSH keys pair.

For the infrastructure authentication process, the first step requires the user’s private SSH key to authenticate against the public SSH key on the host, access to the private key is protected through a secret passphrase. Unique identifiers are established for each 2 Twelve E3LabIaaS administrator account through unique user IDs. User accounts and initial temporary passwords will be set up as follows:

• The CloudOps team creates user accounts and distributes initial temporary passwords through email, or by separate channels such as slack or phone.

• Initial temporary passwords cannot be blank and must be set to force change at first login.

• Each user must have a unique ID and password, and may not access environments without individual identification.

Customer Responsibility:

It is the customer responsibility to verify the identity of the individual, group, role or device as part of the initial authenticator distribution.

his control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

2 Twelve personnel who require administrator access to the E3LabIaaS environment are verified as part of the hiring process. The hiring process includes a background check to include the verification of the individual’s identity and address. As part of the team onboarding process the 2 Twelve personnel with administrator access to E3LabIaaS creates required unique SSH keys pair.

For the infrastructure authentication process, the first step requires the user’s private SSH key to authenticate against the public SSH key on the host, access to the private key is protected through a secret passphrase. Unique identifiers are established for each 2 Twelve E3LabIaaS administrator account through unique user IDs. User accounts and initial temporary passwords will be set up as follows:

• The CloudOps team creates user accounts and distributes initial temporary passwords through email, or by separate channels such as slack or phone.

• Initial temporary passwords cannot be blank and must be set to force change at first login.

• Each user must have a unique ID and password, and may not access environments without individual identification.

Customer Responsibility:

It is the customer responsibility to verify the identity of the individual, group, role or device as part of the initial authenticator distribution.

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

2 Twelve Policy and Procedures Identification and Authentication, governs 2 Twelve E3LabIaaS user accounts and authenticators. Issued passwords meet 2 Twelve policy requirements respectively for password complexity.

Strong passwords and passphrases must meet the following requirements:

• Contain at least twelve alphanumeric characters

• Contain both upper and lower case letters.

• Contain at least one number (for example, 0-9).

• Contain at least one special character (for example,!$%^&*()_+|~-=\`{}[]:";'<>?,/)

Application: 2 Twelve managed application credentials are consistent with requirements in IA-5(1). Customer access to 2 Twelve managed applications use HTTPS with TLS v1.2 utilizing customer provided credentials.

Operating System:  Authorized 2 Twelve administrators access operating systems by authenticating via SSH to the host.  All users must have a valid SSH key. 2 Twelve utilizes SSH key pairs generated using at least RSA 2048 bit  size key or ECC of equivalent strength.

Customer Responsibility:

It is the customer responsibility to ensure that authenticators have sufficient strength of mechanism for the application environment.

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

Lost, compromised, or damaged authenticators are revoked from being used. Users are required to report to their managers when passwords are lost, compromised, or damaged. The 2 Twelve Access and Identity Management Plan establish procedure for administrating authenticators.

When a FIPS 140-2 authenticator needs to be replaced due to damage, loss, or theft an administrator revokes the authenticator. 2 Twelve employees are responsible for protecting authenticator devices used in accessing E3LabIaas environments. For lost, stolen, compromised or damaged authenticator devices, employees must immediately perform the following steps:

• Send an email to CloudOps explaining that the device can no longer be used and include the reason

• CloudOps reinitiates a new token to the user following the setup process once the user obtains a new device

Customer Responsibility:

It is the customer responsibility to establish and implement administrative procedures for initial authenticator distribution, for lost/compromised or damaged authenticators, and for revoking authenticators for the E3LabIaas application environment.

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

All user passwords for access to the 2 Twelve E3LabIaas environment are required to be changed upon initial user logon. All default authenticators are required to be changed for all new components that are added to the 2 Twelve E3LabIaas environment.

Application, Database, Operating System:  All default authenticators are required to be changed for all new components that are added to the 2 Twelve E3LabIaas environment. Installation of new devices must comply with the password complexity requirements outlined in control IA-5(1). Default passwords for devices in the authorization boundary are changed prior to go live. The current Ansible playbook update configurations to prevent the root account from being used for remote access during the initial deployment of the instance.

Customer Responsibility:

It is the customer responsibility to ensure the default content of authenticators are changed prior to information system installation for the E3LabIaas application environment.

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

Application: E3LabIaas tools enforce minimum and maximum lifetime restriction and reuse conditions. Minimum lifetime is set at minimum of 1 day, maximum lifetime is set at 90 days, and reuse conditions are set at 24.

Operating System:  All hosts instances enforce minimum and maximum lifetime restriction and reuse conditions. Minimum lifetime is set at minimum of 1 day, maximum lifetime is set at 90 days, and reuse conditions are set at 24.

Customer Responsibility:

It is the customer responsibility to establish minimum and maximum lifetime restrictions and reuse conditions for authenticators for the E3LabIaas application environment.

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

E3LabIaas enforce refreshing authenticators through password expiration setting. For all password settings, password expiration is set for 60 or 90 days, defined as the maximum lifetime restriction.

Application: E3LabIaas tools enforce minimum and maximum lifetime restriction and reuse conditions. Minimum lifetime is set at minimum of 1 day, maximum lifetime is set at 90 days, reuse conditions are set at 24

Operating System:  The bastion host and all hosts instances enforce minimum and maximum lifetime restriction and reuse conditions. Minimum lifetime is set at minimum of 1 day, maximum lifetime is set at 90 days, and reuse conditions are set at 24.

Customer Responsibility:

It is the customer responsibility to change or refresh authenticators within their organizational defined time period for all authenticators for the E3LabIaas application environment.

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

2 Twelve administrators are required to protect authenticator content from unauthorized disclosure and modification. The protection of authenticator content is required under the 2 Twelve E3LabIaas Rules of Behavior and the Access and Identify Management Plan. Users who do not comply with the 2 Twelve E3LabIaas Rules of Behavior may incur disciplinary action, including but not limited to employment termination and/or criminal prosecution.

Application: E3LabIaas tools obscure feedback of authentication during the authentication process and does not display password in plain text.

Operating System: All OS instances obscure feedback of authentication during the authentication process and does not display password in plain text. SSH passwords are stored in hashed format using SHA-512.

Customer Responsibility:

It is the customer responsibility to protect authenticator content from unauthorized disclosure and modification for all accounts with access to the E3LabIaas application environment.

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

CloudOps maintains password management system features and functionality to include:

• Allow users to select and change their own passwords and include a confirmation procedure to allow for input errors

• Enforce password complexity

• Force users to change their passwords at first log-on

• Enforce regular password changes with a maximum password lifetime of 60 or 90 days

• Obscure passwords on the screen when being entered

• Authenticators are encrypted in storage and transmission

Application, Database, Operating System:  2 Twelve maintains password management system features and functionality. The 2 Twelve Rules of Behavior document the require security safeguards. The Rules of Behavior is signed by all members of CloudOps. The protection of authenticator content is required under the 2 Twelve E3LabIaas Rules of Behavior. Users who do not comply with the 2 Twelve E3LabIaas Rules of Behavior may incur disciplinary action, including but not limited to employment termination and/or criminal prosecution. In addition, all local passwords are stored within Linux as hashed values.

Customer Responsibility:

It is the customer responsibility to ensure requires individuals to take, and have devices implement, specific security safeguards to protect authenticators for the E3LabIaas application environment.

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

E3LabIaas does not utilize group accounts.

Application, Database, Operating System:  This part of IA-5 is not applicable for the E3LabIaas environment as 2 Twelve E3LabIaas does not utilize group accounts.

Customer Responsibility:

It is the customer responsibility to change authenticators for group/role accounts when membership to those accounts changes for the E3LabIaas application environment.

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

2 Twelve enforces minimum password complexity requirements for 2 Twelve E3LabIaas password-based authentication.

Strong passwords and passphrases must meet the following requirements:

• Contain at least twelve alphanumeric characters in accordance with NIST SP 800-63B Memorized Secret (Section 5.1.1) Guidance

• Contain both upper and lower case letters.

• Contain at least one number (for example, 0-9).

• Contain at least one special character (for example,!$%^&*()_+|~-=\`{}[]:";'<>?,/).

Application: E3LabIaas tools enforce password complexity and length via SSO and identity provider configurations.

Operating System:  All hosts instances enforce key only SSH access. CloudOps has the admin privilege to edit those settings through ansible playbook.

Customer Responsibility:

It is the customer responsibility to enforce minimum password complexity to include the following organization-defined requirements for case sensitivity, number of characters, mix of upper-case letters, lower-case letters, numbers, and special characters for the E3LabIaas application environment.

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

All passwords must have at least one (1) new character when changed. This is enforced through password reuse, users cannot change the new password with his or her existing password.

Application: E3LabIaas tools enforce minimum and maximum lifetime restriction and reuse conditions. Minimum lifetime is set at minimum of 1 day, maximum lifetime is set at 60 days, reuse conditions are set at 24.

Operating System:  All hosts instances enforce minimum and maximum lifetime restriction and reuse conditions. Minimum lifetime is set at minimum of 1 day, maximum lifetime is set at 90 days, and reuse conditions are set at 24.

Customer Responsibility:

It is the customer responsibility to enforce that when new passwords are created at least one character must be changed for the E3LabIaas application passwords and/or passphrases.

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

E3LabIaas authenticators are encrypted in storage and transmission. E3LabIaas does not have any passwords or authenticators transmit or store in clear text within or across the authorization boundary.

Application: E3LabIaas tools obscure feedback of authentication during the authentication process and does not display password in plain text.

Operating System: All OS instances obscure feedback of authentication during the authentication process and does not display password in plain text. SSH passwords are hashed using SHA-512.

Customer Responsibility:

It is the customer responsibility to store and transmit only cryptographically-protected passwords.

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

2 Twelve has established minimum and maximum lifetime restrictions, where configurable, as follows:

• Minimum and password ages are not configurable

• Maximum password age of 90 days

Application, Database, Operating System:  2 Twelve has established minimum and maximum lifetime restrictions. The above minimum and maximum lifetime restrictions apply for the E3LabIaas tools and operating system. SHA-512 hashing is used to protect SSH passwords from disclosure and modification.

Customer Responsibility:

It is the customer responsibility to enforce a password minimum and maximum lifetime restrictions.

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

2 Twelve prohibits password reuse of, at least, twenty-four generations within the 2 Twelve E3LabIaas environment. The CloudOps team is responsible for the implementation and configuration of the password reuse restrictions for 2 Twelve managed applications.

Application: E3LabIaas tools enforce minimum and maximum lifetime restriction and reuse conditions. Minimum lifetime is set at minimum of 1 day, maximum lifetime is set at 90 days, reuse conditions are set at 24

Operating System:  All hosts instances enforce key only SSH access

Customer Responsibility:

It is the customer responsibility to prohibits password reuse as required by the organizational policy for the E3LabIaas application.

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

2 Twelve uses temporary passwords as a part of the onboarding process for new hires and requires that the password is changed after the initial log in by the user. CloudOps is responsible for configuring each user account to immediately prompt for a new password after the initial login.

Customer Responsibility:

It is the customer responsibility to allow the use of a temporary password for system logons with an immediate change to a permanent password for the E3LabIaas application.

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

Certificate based PKI authentication is not used within 2 Twelve E3LabIaas infrastructure to access any components within the authorization boundary. 2 Twelve E3LabIaas offers the capability to customer to enable PKI based authentication and let the customer choose and make a selection.

Customer Responsibility:

It is the customer responsibility to validate certifications by constructing and verifying a certification path to an accepted trust anchor including checking certificate status information.

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

Certificate based PKI authentication is not used within 2 Twelve E3LabIaas infrastructure to access any components within the authorization boundary. 2 Twelve E3LabIaas offers the capability to customer to enable PKI based authentication and let the customer choose and make a selection.

Customer Responsibility:

It is the customer responsibility to enforce authorized access to the corresponding private key for the E3LabIaas application.

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

Certificate based PKI authentication is not used within 2 Twelve E3LabIaas infrastructure to access any components within the authorization boundary. 2 Twelve E3LabIaas offers the capability to customer to enable PKI based authentication and let the customer choose and make a selection.

Customer Responsibility:

It is the customer responsibility to map the authenticated identity to the account of the individual or group.

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

Certificate based PKI authentication is not used within 2 Twelve E3LabIaas infrastructure to access any components within the authorization boundary. 2 Twelve E3LabIaas offers the capability to customer to enable PKI based authentication and let the customer choose and make a selection.

Customer Responsibility:

It is the customer responsibility to implement a local cache of revocation data to support path discovery and validation in case of inability to access revocation information via the network.

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

2 Twelve requires that the registration process to receive all hardware authenticators be conducted in person with their manager or 2 Twelve appointed representative. As part of the initial authenticator distribution, 2 Twelve verifies the identity of the individual, group, role, or device  receiving the authenticator.

Application, Database, Operating System:  As part of the initial authenticator distribution, 2 Twelve verifies the identity of the individual, group, role, or device receiving the authenticator. The individual’s manager or 2 Twelve appointed representative are responsible for verifying the identity of individual users prior to issuing all hardware multi-factor authenticators.

Customer Responsibility:

It is the customer responsibility to ensure that the registration process to receive all multifactor authenticators comply with their organization’s policies

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

2 Twelve establishes MFA hardware-based tokens that employ the Time-based One-time Password (TOTP) algorithm for infrastructure access. The token used in the E3LabIaas environment for SSH authentication into the hosts.

Customer Responsibility:

It is the customer responsibility to ensure that for hardware token-based authentication employs mechanisms that satisfy their organizational requirements for access to the E3LabIaas application.

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

2 Twelve obscures authenticator feedback via built-in operating system settings that protect password inputs when the authentication process occurs. Authenticator feedback are either hidden or obscured with the use of asterisks (*). Additionally, 2 Twelve obscures authenticator feedback for customer-facing web applications and passwords are displayed as asterisks at the login screen.

Application: E3LabIaas tools obscure password via SSO and identity provider configurations.

Operating System:  All hosts instances enforce key only SSH access. CloudOps has the admin privilege to edit those settings through ansible playbook.

Customer Responsibility:

It is the customer responsibility to ensure the information system obscures feedback of authentication information during the authentication process to protect the information from possible exploitation/use by unauthorized individuals.

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

E3LabIaas implements FIPS-validated cryptographic modules, which provide mechanisms for authentication to a cryptographic module which meet the requirements of applicable federal laws, Executive Orders, directives, policies, regulations, standards, and guidance for such authentication. All access to the applications via web service and API are through reverse proxies which enforce HTTPS via TLS v1.2.

Application: Access to 2 Twelve managed applications occurs over HTTPS via TLS v1.2 or above.

Operating System: Authorized 2 Twelve administrators access operating systems by authenticating through the host via SSH. All users must have a valid SSH key. 2 Twelve utilizes SSH key pairs generated using RSA 2048 bit size key or greater strength. Users must have a matching public SSH key on the operating system to establish connection with that host.

Customer Responsibility:

It is the customer responsibility to ensure the information system implements mechanisms for authentication to a cryptographic module that meet the requirements of applicable federal laws, Executive Orders, directives, policies, regulations, standards, and guidance for such authentication.

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

The only non-organizational users that authenticate to the system are customer users. Customer users authenticate to their own agencies’ identity management solutions and access E3LabIaas with a SAML token presented by the customer identity management solution. Customer requirements are detailed throughout the IA-2(2) controls.

Application, Database, Operating System:  There are no non-organizational users with access to the E3LabIaas. The only non-organizational users that authenticate to the system are customer users. Customer users authenticate to their own agencies’ identity management solutions and access E3LabIaas with a SAML token presented by the customer identity management solution. 2 Twelve E3LabIaas supports federated authentication for user SSO using SAML 2.0 or MFA.

Customer Responsibility:

It is the customer responsibility to ensure the information system uniquely identifies and authenticates non-organizational users to the E3LabIaas application.

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

Verification of PIV credentials is a customer responsibility and will be carried out by customer identity management systems. After successful authentication SAML assertions will be transmitted from the customer identity management systems to E3LabIaas.

Application, Database, Operating System:  Customers are responsible for implementing PIV cards and CAC if they choose to. The E3LabIaas application lets the customer implement the SAML 2.0 SSO of their choosing. After authentication, SAML assertions will be transmitted from the customer identity management systems to E3LabIaas system.

Customer Responsibility:

It is the customer responsibility to enable and verify Personal Identity Verification (PIV) credentials from other federal agencies.

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

All verification of third party credentials will be carried out by customer identity management systems. It is a customer responsibility to configure their identity management systems to accept only FICAM-approved third-party credentials.

Application, Database, Operating System: The E3LabIaas environment accepts FICAM credentials in the form of a SAML token; however this control requirement is met by the customer’s implementation. Customers are responsible to configure their identity management systems to accept only FICAM-approved third-party credentials. The E3LabIaas application lets the customer implement the SAML 2.0 SSO of their choosing.

Customer Responsibility:

It is the customer responsibility to ensure that their multifactor authentication solution accepts only FICAM-approved third-party credentials.

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

All verification of third party credentials will be carried out by customer identity management systems. It is a customer responsibility to employ only FICAM-approved information system components in their identity management system to accept third-party credentials.

Application, Database, Operating System: Customers are responsible for employing only FICAM-approved information system components. The E3LabIaas application lets the customer implement the SAML 2.0 SSO of their choosing.

Customer Responsibility:

It is the customer responsibility to ensure that their organization employs only FICAM- approved information system components in their SSO solutions accept third-party credentials.

This control is reviewed at least annually or as needed by the ISSO and SO.

2 Twelve Responsibility:

E3LabIaas accepts SAML tokens from customer identity management systems, it does not establish identity management standards for any Federal entity, implement CAC or PIV identification or authentication solutions or issue CACs or PIV cards.

Application, Database, Operating System: E3LabIaas accepts SAML tokens from customer identity management systems, it does not establish identity management standards for any Federal entity, implement CAC or PIV identification or authentication solutions or issue CACs or PIV cards. It is a customer responsibility to configure their identity management systems to conform to FICAM-issued profiles.

Customer Responsibility:

It is a customer responsibility to implement identity management systems that conform to FICAM-issued profiles.

60f92bcf-f353-4236-9803-2a5d417555f4.remarks:
The component-uuid above points to the "this system" component.

Any control response content that does not cleanly fit another system component is placed here. This includes customer responsibility content.

This can also be used to provide a summary, such as a holistic overview of how multiple components work together.

While the "this system" component is not expclicity required within every `statement`, it will typically be present.
